title: SOLVED: 820-01700 - 20V 0.17A after liquid damage. Short on PP*_SLPDDR & Heat signature on T2
message:
Hi Guys, this A2141 820-01700 came with liquid damage on 2 spots only:

C6466/6452 - PPBUS_G3H_SPKRPAML - 12.6V - 0.39
C9580 - PPBUS_g3H_SSD0_SNS - 12.6V - 0.39

The only short I located apart from than CPU Phase lines is on
PP0V9_SLPDDR - 0.049
PP0V82_SLPDDR - 0.032
PPVDCPU_AWAKE - 0.010

There is a heat signature on T2 when power is applied where the current goes 0.01A - 0.17A - 0.01A

[ATTACH]60640[/ATTACH][ATTACH]60641[/ATTACH][ATTACH]60642[/ATTACH]

title: SOLVED: 820-01700 - 20V 0.17A after liquid damage. Short on PP*_SLPDDR & Heat signature on T2
message:
There are the readings I got from good board:
L7806-09   018
L7811/12   047
L7816/17   105
Is normal to have differences with other board, but 049 looks to low, comparing with 105.

Check diode mode at L9520/80 too.

title: SOLVED: 820-01700 - 20V 0.17A after liquid damage. Short on PP*_SLPDDR & Heat signature on T2
SOLVED: 820-01700 - 20V 0.17A after liquid damage. Short on PP*_SLPDDR & Heat signature on T2
message:
Do you get all SLPS2R and AWAKE voltages?
Also check SSD and G3S voltages.

title: SOLVED: 820-01700 - 20V 0.17A after liquid damage. Short on PP*_SLPDDR & Heat signature on T2
message:
SLPS2R - 0.8, 1.1, 1.8present
PPVDDCPU_AWAKE - 0.5V - is it low?
PPVDDCPUSRAM_AWAKE - 0.8V
AWAKE -1.2,  1.8, 3.3

PPBUS_G3H_SSD0_SNS - 12V
PP2V5_NAND_SSD0 - 2.5V
PP3V3_G3H_SSD0_SNS - 3.3v

title: SOLVED: 820-01700 - 20V 0.17A after liquid damage. Short on PP*_SLPDDR & Heat signature on T2
SOLVED: 820-01700 - 20V 0.17A after liquid damage. Short on PP*_SLPDDR & Heat signature on T2
message:
Thank [USER=682]@2informaticos[/USER]  this resolved it. Not sure how liquid damage is related to DFu corruption. :/
The minute I start pushing into DFU mode and the meter connected to the top left port, it starts pulling above 2A and charging the battery.
Fallowed this - [URL]https://iboysoft.com/wiki/dfu-mode-mac.html[/URL] and did Restore from this - [URL]https://support.apple.com/en-au/guide/apple-configurator-mac/apdebea5be51/mac[/URL]

Wiped the data but that's fine. Now I need to replace the keyboard. 

Has anyone tried[URL='https://www.aliexpress.com/item/1005003506664778.html'] these screws[/URL] for keyboard replacement on new macs? [URL='https://www.aliexpress.com/item/4000322162707.html']These ones I have[/URL] are a bit long and the keyboard profile sags.
